title-group.subtitle: Implications and Strategies for Public Health Prevention and Interventions

author-notes.corresp: Monica H. Swahn, PhD, Institute of Public Health, Partnership for Urban Health Research, Georgia State University, P.O. Box 3995, Atlanta, GA 30302-3995, USA Email: MSwahn@gsu.edu

fn.p: Monica H. Swahn is an epidemiologist and associate professor in public health at Georgia State University, Atlanta, USA. Her primary research interests pertain to the prevention of alcohol and drug use, violence and injuries among adolescents and young adults in the United States, Europe, and Africa, with an emphasis on vulnerable populations.

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Early Adolescent Health in Cross-National Perspective

abstract.p: The current special issue brings together intriguing and important cross-country comparisons of issues pertinent to early adolescence that can inform the design and implementation of broader and relevant public health prevention strategies. The findings illustrate the importance of cross-country analyses for better understanding a range of health-related factors, including risk behaviors, mental health concerns, life satisfaction, and parent–child communication and relationships. The findings also underscore the convergence across countries and cultures of risk and protective factors as well as their associations with adverse health outcomes. Taken as a whole, the findings demonstrate that there are different unmet needs among girls and boys. As such, the findings stress the importance of providing youth with targeted prevention approaches and also, where feasible, sex-specific prevention and intervention strategies to direct scarce resources where they are most urgently needed.

body.p: One in every five person in the world is an adolescent (United Nations Children’s Fund [UNICEF], 2009; United Nations Population Fund [UNFPA], 2009). Analyses of the causes of death for adolescent boys and girls 10 to 14 years of age indicate that lower respiratory tract infections, road traffic injuries, drowning, malaria, and meningitis are the top five leading causes of death followed by HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, diarrheal diseases, malnutrition, and self-inflicted injuries (Patton et al., 2009). Although these causes of death vary for boys and girls, across countries and regions, they underscore the importance of increasing efforts to examine mental health concerns and health risk behaviors linked to injuries and other adverse health conditions in this age group.

Public health prevention strategies that target adolescents represent an important priority, not only to prevent mortality in this age group but also because nearly two thirds of premature deaths and one third of the total disease burden in adults are associated with conditions and health behaviors that were initiated earlier in life (World Health Organization [WHO], 2011). These conditions and health behaviors include substance use, lack of physical activity, unprotected sex, and exposure to violence (WHO, 2011). It is clear that the adolescent life stage, a time of vulnerability, is a critically important period for prevention (UNICEF, 2011). In response to these concerns, the current special issue brings together intriguing and important cross-country comparisons of topics pertinent to early adolescence that can inform the design and implementation of broader and relevant public health prevention strategies.

Three manuscripts (Farhat et al., 2012; de Looze et al., 2012; Ottova et al., 2012) address important health risk behaviors and mental health concerns across countries to better understand similarities and differences in country-specific patterns. With respect to the determinants of psychosomatic complaints, the findings show that psychosomatic complaints varied greatly between the countries examined and that adolescents who live in less privileged countries report more psychosomatic complaints, even when other stressors were considered (Ottova et al., 2012). Moreover, the study found that psychosomatic complaints were higher among girls than among boys (Ottova et al., 2012) likely indicating more unmet mental health and service needs among girls.

Another study found that perceived peer and adolescent alcohol use was significantly associated across countries, even though the strength of that association varied (Farhat et al., 2012). Consistent with earlier research (Dick et al., 2007; Kokkevi, Richardson, Florescu, Kuzman, & Stergar, 2007) these findings were stronger for girls than for boys (Farhat et al., 2012), possibly because it is less normative and prevalent for girls than for boys to be drinking alcohol in this age group (Simons-Morton et al., 2009). Moreover, the examination of initiation or onset of several high-risk behaviors (i.e., early smoking, early drunkenness, early cannabis use, and early sexual intercourse) show that there is quite a range of these high-risk behaviors across countries (de Looze et al., 2012). However, the associations between early initiation of these risk behaviors and reporting medically treated injuries at age 15 were surprisingly robust across countries (de Looze et al., 2012). These findings are supported by previous research that has reported a link between early alcohol and drug use initiation and suicidal and violent behaviors among youth across a range of settings (Swahn & Bossarte, 2007; Swahn, Bossarte, Ashby, & Meyers, 2010; Swahn et al., 2011; Swahn, Bossarte, & Sullivent, 2008). Taken as a whole, these findings indirectly suggest that delaying involvement in high-risk behaviors could possibly prevent or reduce injuries (de Looze et al., 2012).

In terms of prevention, it is well recognized that family functioning, parental monitoring, and parent–adolescent communication are key markers of adolescent health, which is why parents are often actively engaged in interventions and prevention strategies that seek to reach adolescents (DiClemente et al., 2001; Jackson & Dickinson, 2009; Schwarz et al., 2012; Tabak et al., 2012). Two of the manuscripts address these issues specifically (Schwarz et al., 2012; Tabak et al., 2012). The importance of parent–child relationships is underscored by its link to life satisfaction (Schwarz et al., 2012). Intriguingly, it appears that there is a convergence of parent–adolescent communication across countries over time (Tabak et al., 2012). The authors suggest that these findings may reflect an overall globalization of media use and cultural practices (Esmer, 2006; Kuntsche et al., 2011, 2009; Tabak et al., 2012), which have intriguing implications for strategies that promote the quality of family life. With respect to parent and peer relationships and life satisfaction, the findings show a positive relationship between parental admiration and adolescent’s life satisfaction across the countries examined (Schwartz et al., 2012). However, important cultural differences were noted with respect to peer acceptance (Schwartz et al., 2012). In addition, girls were less satisfied with their lives than were boys (Schwartz et al., 2012), which again underscores the grave needs of adolescent girls (UNICEF, 2011).

The findings from these studies, taken as a whole, urge us to pursue and promote a renewed interest and investment in adolescent health (UNICEF, 2011; WHO, 2010). The findings also illustrate the importance of cross-country analyses for better understanding a range of health-related factors, their contexts, and possible solutions. More specifically, the findings underscore the convergence across countries and cultures of risk and protective factors as well as their associations with adverse health outcomes. These findings may reflect new and intriguing levels of globalization that should be examined more closely in future research. Finally, the findings also clearly demonstrate that there are different unmet needs among girls and boys. As such, the findings stress the importance of providing youth with targeted prevention approaches and also, where feasible, sex-specific prevention and intervention strategies to direct scarce resources where they are most urgently needed.

fn.p: The author declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
The author received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
